Technical Assistance Report 
 
 
Project Number: 54246-001 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
October 2020 
 
 
 
 
Impact Evaluation of Financial Technology 
Innovations in Selected Developing Member 
Countries 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB’s Access to Information 
Policy.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
COVID-19  –  coronavirus disease 
DMC  –  developing member country 
ERCD  –  Economic Research and Regional Cooperation Department 
IE  –  impact evaluation 
IoT  –  internet of things 
SDSC-FIN  –  Finance Sector Group of the Sustainable Development and 
Climate Change Department 
TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to United States dollars. 
 
 
 
 
Vice-President  Bambang Susantono, Knowledge Management and Sustainable 
Development 
Director General  Yasuyuki Sawada, Economic Research and Regional Cooperation 
Department (ERCD) 
Director  Rana Hasan, Economic Analysis and Operational Support Division 
(EREA), ERCD 
   
Team leader  Takashi Yamano, Senior Economist, EREA, ERCD  
Team members  Aileen Gatson, Senior Operations Assistant, EREA, ERCD 
Lilibeth Poot, Senior Economics Officer, EREA, ERCD 
David Anthony Raitzer, Economist, EREA, ERCD

of  or  reference  to  a  particular  territory  or  geographic  area  in  this  document,  the  Asian 
Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status of any 
territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) aims to support the conduct of 
impact evaluation (IE) studies on the use of financial technology in developing member countries 
(DMCs) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB).1 This is in line with ADB’s overall support for 
evidence-based policy development. Based on the findings of the IE studies, lessons will be 
drawn to inform ADB operation teams and DMC officers in designing future ADB-financed projects. 
Financial technology can potentially enhance the conduct of business, limit person-to-person 
contact, and sustain business operations during pandemics and disasters. In the face of the 
coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic, financial technology has helped to enable financial 
transactions and goods deliveries when personal mobility has been restricted. 
 
2.  The  TA  supports  ADB’s  Strategy  2030  guiding  principle  of  promoting  innovative 
technology. In particular, it aligns with operational priority 1 (addressing remaining poverty and 
reducing inequalities) and operational priority 2 (accelerating progress in gender equality).2 The 
TA is not part of the Economic Research and Regional Cooperation Department (ERCD) annual 
work program for 2020.3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  In response to COVID-19, governments across Asia have undertaken lockdown measures 
that have restricted economic activity and adversely affected the cash flows of businesses and 
households. As social distancing has taken hold worldwide, there has been tremendous growth 
in the use of financial technology.4 Recent advances in financial technology provide opportunities 
for ADB and DMCs to improve the effectiveness of projects to respond to the challenges of a 
pandemic. However, the use of advanced financial technology in public projects remains novel, 
and evidence of its effectiveness under COVID-19-related lockdowns and movement restrictions 
remains thin. Meanwhile, financial technology continues to advance, leaving many technologies 
untested for public sector application. 
 
4.  In parallel, financial technology is becoming accessible to users at a low cost. More big 
data  on  financial  transactions  are  increasingly  available  through  automated  processes. 
Administrative and billing information is increasingly accumulated wherein such data could be 
linked with other databases to broaden credit access.5 Financial information could also be linked 
with assets through the internet of things (IoT) to track loan servicing.6 Digital identification 
systems give governments and businesses the ability to deliver services electronically, boosting 
efficiency and driving innovation. E-payment systems, for instance, could ease tax payments and 
 
1  Financial technology refers to internet-based and other digital technology that supports or enables banking and 
financial services. Examples relevant to ADB operations include digitized national identity records used for providing 
public services, digital credit tracking, blockchain-based payment systems, credit services using the internet of things 
(IoT), and mobile phone- or internet-based financial transactions. 
2  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila. 
3  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 15 October 2020. 
4  S. Whitelaw et al. 2020. Applications of Digital Technology in COVID-19 Pandemic Planning and Response. Lancet 
Digital Health. 2 (8): E435–E440. 
5  For example, by using advanced analytics platforms and artificial intelligence to assess transactional and alternative 
data (something as simple as a bank statement that shows the cash flow of a small and medium-sized enterprise), 
financial technology lenders are gaining a much deeper understanding of small and medium-sized enterprises. They 
can establish businesses' creditworthiness, evaluate risk more easily, and release loans in as few as 1–2 days. 
6  An example is IoT-based auto loans in the Philippines, provided by Aeon Credit Service (Philippines) and a financial 
technology startup called Global Mobility Service. Defaults on loan payments result in deactivation of vehicles, after 
multiple warnings and when vehicles are safely parked.

2 
administration, improving tax compliance and revenue. Digital identification systems connect 
isolated and unreached populations to government subsidies, electoral participation, financial 
services,  educational  and  job  opportunities,  and  health  care.  Through  the  use  of  digital 
identification systems, social protection programs could be linked with identity and banking 
information of recipients to enable delivery of these programs.7 At the same time, however, there 
is an urgent need to identify risks and vulnerabilities, such as misuse, security breaches, and 
other illegal uses, in digital technology. 
 
5.  As the COVID-19 pandemic continues to create uncertainty and as economies endeavor 
to shift from response to recovery, it is the right time to gather evidence on the effectiveness of 
interventions that use financial technology. Future applications will be better informed about 
whether to replicate, continue, modify, and/or scale up financial technology-related interventions.8 
 
6.  While a few ADB-assisted projects have adopted advanced financial technology that can 
make financial processes, such as payments to project beneficiaries, more efficient, discussions 
between project officers and government counterparts regarding its use are increasingly common. 
The use of financial technology in ADB-assisted projects will benefit from reliable evidence on its 
effectiveness. Thus, the TA will select and support studies that will examine the use of advanced 
financial technology and draw lessons from these studies to inform the design of future ADB 
projects. The TA will examine past or ongoing ADB projects that use financial technology and/or 
pilot projects that can be considered for future ADB projects.9 
 
7.  IE is essential for realizing ADB’s Strategy 2030 vision of becoming a leading knowledge 
provider in Asia and the Pacific. The need for knowledge is especially high when it comes to new 
technologies. Thus, the TA will evaluate the use of financial technology, draw lessons to benefit 
the design of ADB projects, and raise awareness of the possibilities and advantages it presents. 
The TA will share the findings of the IE studies in reports and workshops to help improve the 
development and design of ADB investment projects that rely on financial technology in DMCs. 
Priority will be given to interventions relevant to COVID-19 management and recovery. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: development effectiveness of ADB projects 
using financial technology enhanced. The impact also supports ADB’s Strategy 2030 operational 
priorities 1 and 2 (para. 2). The TA will have the following outcome: application of financial 
technology in ADB projects increased.10 
 
 
 
 
 
7  Digital identification systems have been introduced recently in Cambodia, India, the Lao People’s Democratic 
Republic, the Philippines, and Viet Nam. 
8  By conducting IE studies, this TA will identify constraints, such as ineffective regulatory frameworks, insufficient 
networks and infrastructure, and weaknesses in digital identification systems, for adopting financial technology in 
government and ADB programs. 
9  For instance, the IE studies could be conducted with project teams before or during project implementation periods, 
and study findings could be included in knowledge and project reports. 
10 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

3 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
9.  Output 1: Impact evaluation studies on the use of financial technology conducted. 
This output will support the conduct of at least three IE studies on the use of financial technology.11 
The IE studies will draw lessons to inform ADB operation teams and DMC officials as they develop 
future ADB-financed projects. The IE studies will be completed within the TA implementation 
period. This will require the design of proposed studies to rely on existing baseline surveys, use 
quasi-experimental methods, or adopt a nimble randomized control trial. Gender-differentiated 
analysis will be conducted in at least one study. 
  
10.  Output 2: Awareness on impact evaluation of financial technology enhanced. This 
output will entail dissemination of IE results on financial technology and policy dialogue with DMC 
officials. The TA will disseminate the information and knowledge generated to policy makers, 
researchers,  ADB  operations  and  knowledge departments,  and  other  stakeholders through 
conferences, workshops, and webinars and other virtual platforms. Audiences will include, in 
particular, policy makers, researchers, other relevant stakeholders in the countries of study, and 
relevant ADB project teams. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
11.  The TA is estimated to cost $500,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by the 
Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund and administered by ADB. The key 
expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2. 
 
12.  The Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund will finance operational 
expenses  related  to  eligible  activities  indicated  in  Article  2  of  the  fund’s  implementation 
guidelines.12 It will not be used for (i) civil works, (ii) procurement of large-scale equipment, (iii) 
permanent staffing costs, or (iv) hiring of staff consultants, unless otherwise agreed between the 
Government of the Republic of Korea and ADB. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
13.  ADB will be the executing agency for the TA. Implementation of the TA is expected to 
commence in November 2020.13 Guidance and expertise will be provided by the Finance Sector 
Group of the Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department (SDSC-FIN), wherein 
SDSC-FIN will ensure sector relevance. ERCD will ensure technical quality of data collection, 
analysis, and knowledge products. 
 
14.  A call for expressions of interest will be made by ERCD to relevant ADB project teams on 
potential interventions for testing through IE. The selection of submissions will be based on cost-
effectiveness, operational relevance, technical rigor, feasibility, and contribution to knowledge 
gaps. In addition, financial technology projects that are specifically targeted at youth, women, and 
economically  challenged  groups  will  be  prioritized.  ERCD  staff  will  support  the  technical 
development of submissions and SDSC-FIN will be consulted on the selection of proposals. The 
selection process will consider gender-differentiated analysis along with relevance to COVID-19 
management and recovery.14 
 
11 Examples include a study on financial technology loans for tricycle drivers in the Philippines and smart electricity 
meter projects in India, Nepal, Tajikistan, and Uzbekistan. 
12 ADB. 2019. Annual Report of the e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund 2018. Manila (Appendix 6). 
13 ADB-financed activities will only commence after receiving a no-objection from each participating DMC. 
14  At least one of the studies to be selected should conduct a gender-differentiated analysis.

4 
 
15.  The results of the IE studies will be published as reports or as stand-alone working papers 
and disseminated at awareness events and policy dialogues. Each IE study will require a team of 
consultants, both international and national, to be engaged separately.15 The consultants will (i) 
provide technical guidance and feedback on the initial IE concept, (ii) develop the design of the 
IE  studies  together  with  ADB  project  teams,  (iii)  assist  in  guiding  and  overseeing  the 
implementation of IE studies, (iv) assist in survey and sampling design, (v) implement the surveys, 
and (vi) assist in data analysis and report preparation. Because some findings from the selected 
studies may be context specific, care will be taken in understanding which aspects can be 
generalized to other contexts and under what conditions. 
 
16.  Implementation arrangements are summarized in the table.

5 
e  ADB. 2018. Administering Grant-Financed Technical Assistance Projects. Project Administration Instructions. PAI 
5.09. Manila. 
Source: ADB. 
 
17.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated staff instructions.16 Although the 
exact requirements of the type of expertise and the length of their inputs will only be known during 
the implementation of the individual studies, it is envisaged that the TA will require about 10 
person-months of international and 10 person-months of national consultant services. Given this 
limitations and the intermittent nature of assignments and highly specialized expertise required, 
the TA will primarily fulfill its consulting requirements by recruiting experts on an individual basis 
through either consultants’ qualifications selection or the direct contracting method. Since there 
are only a few individuals with specialized expertise in IE and financial technology, the proposed 
selection methods are deemed justified. If the studies require involvement of a research institution, 
the recruitment will be based on consultants’ qualifications selection. On an exceptional basis, 
and where the project or study selections result in a country context where only one research 
institution can provide the required expertise, the recruitment will be conducted on a single-source 
selection  basis  or  using  the  direct  contracting  method.  Outline  terms  of  reference  for  the 
consultants are in Appendix 3. ADB will also engage experts, which could include ADB staff, as 
resource  persons  to  produce  knowledge  products  and  facilitate  workshops,  trainings,  and 
conferences. 
 
18.  ADB’s  procurement.  ADB  will  engage  consultants  and  carry  out  procurement  (for 
consulting services and equipment) following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended 
from time to time) and its associated staff instructions. Non-consulting services for separately 
contracted data collection will be procured using open advertisement or request for quotation. 
Procurement of equipment will take place in coordination with ADB’s Office of Information 
Systems and Technology and Office of Administrative Services. When the TA is completed, any 
procured equipment will remain ADB property and/or will be disposed of in accordance with 
relevant ADB guidelines. Disbursements under the TA will be made in accordance with ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2020, as amended from time to time). 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the Asian 
Development Bank administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 
to be financed on a grant basis by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund 
for Impact Evaluation of Financial Technology Innovations in Selected Developing Member 
Countries, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
 
16 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).
